This is probably not what you want to hear, but short answer is .... you don't.

Unless you want to be doing an EECS lab's equivalent of doing dirty dishes (or in the case of some EE labs, literally doing dirty dishes), you need more knowledge. At this level, you're probably gonna end up doing scripting work at most for a non-EECS lab, which really isn't meaningful experience.

Judging by the fact that you're a sophomore, you probably haven't taken 61C yet. To be useful, ideally, you want to have 2 or 3 upper-division courses in your area of interest before you'll start getting positive responses. For now, focus on your coursework, and look for research in the coming spring or next fall.

---------------

I would highly recommend looking for research experience at LBNL instead of Cal. Scientists there are more caring and responsive than professors. Try to email them.

I do research at LBNL and it is amazing. When I was looking for an opportunity, I emailed three staff scientists and all of them responded to me within 8 hours.

My group has about 25 people and there are only two students (me and some masters student from Germany). I am directly supervised by a scientist and PI who both have 30 years of experience because there are not many students. I get a lot of attention and receive a lot of guidance because the scientists see mentoring as a rewarding activity, not a choir. For example, my PI and the other scientist insisted on discussing my course schedule with me, took me to collaborator meetings to help me understand how funding and collaboration work, sent me links to lab training workshops when they know the topic interests me, and got me a paid student assistant position. I can choose which project I want to work on and there is a big emphasis that I don't do menial and repetitive tasks because "I am there to learn." 

There are so many resources that you can access at LBNL that are not available to undergraduate researchers at Cal. For example, I was able to get professional headshot, attend various workshops on machine learning and career seminars, and unofficially participate in undergraduate research internship program (weekly discussions with scientists, tours at the lab, poster presentations).

children.subject: <md>As a person who got research Spring semester of sophomore here, I think I can give you some advice on how to go from random person to not random person! I figured out what lab(s) I was interested in working in at the end of the summer before sophomore here. I considered what I wanted to do and what would be interesting. At this point I was just out of 61B with no (and I mean n o) real coding experience and no research experience (I didn't even have an internship that summer). Once I figured out what areas I was interested in, I signed up for the mailing lists that those labs are on. If you are into AI for instance, BAIR has a general mailing list and most sub areas have their own mailing lists too. I started going to as many talks and meetings I could manage. This serves in two ways - firstly, you understand what people are actually doing in that area. What research is actually going on in Berkeley and other institutions? People don't really update their websites that often but people always present on the newest and most exciting part of their research. Go to these meetings and write down what they are saying and look it up later. You don't need to understand how they do what they do - you need to understand what they do and why. The why is important because most grad students talking to each other don't get into the gritty details of their project. The idea is everyone already kinda knows how research is done and how things are built. They talk about the thing that they are doing and why they are doing it. Once you have gone to these talks for a couple weeks, you need bravery. This will probably be harder online but you need to talk to people! This is a bit like dating I guess, if you go into it just trying to find any grad student to take you, you'll probably not find it. Instead, talk before and after these meetings, email grad students who you've seen at these talks. Discuss what they are doing on a high conceptual level and if you find something interesting, express it! Grad students are where they are because they are excited about what they are working on, so if you show that same energy it will be easier to get to know them. Once you find someone who you vibe with and who's research you like, just ask them if you can work with them. Even if they don't have time or whatever, they will be able to direct you to other grad students who have similar interests and give you a leg up in getting their attention. I disagree with a lot people that you need to know everything before you start research. You should be exploring these topics on your own and have a general understanding of the field but the whole point of being an intern is to learn and the people you'll work under will know that. </md>
<md>Thank you so much for your advice!!! Now I have a much better understanding of what I should be striving for. </md>

<md>Hi there, thank you so much for the other perspective! Tbh I feel this is more helpful than most other info I could find. 
I guess my motivation behind wanting to find a research position is basically to improve my chances of being admitted to a good grad program. I don't know if I want to go to grad school yet but I would like to keep the option open. I look at the offerings at Cal and most of them require some sort of research experience, so I assumed it would be similar for other programs. Also, I guess in order to get good rec letters working with a professor is also necessary? I know I should wait until I learn a bit more, but if I start looking in my junior year and don't find any luck that year, I feel like I am pretty much doomed since I should be finishing up my application that summer. If possible can I get some perspectives on this? Thanks a lot!
I will definitely look into LBNL! Hopefully I can find some luck with them. </md>

history.content:
<md>I know there are already many posts out there that have asked the exact same thing, but I still need a little bit more guidance than what I could find. I am currently a rising sophomore, and I know there are URAP that I could apply through to hopefully get a position in research, which I will try this fall. I don't want to put all the eggs in one basket though, especially I feel having research experience is crucial. I heard someone could get a research position by emailing professors and Ph.D. students, but where can I find information on what they are working on and whether they accept new assistant? I can find a little information on EECS website about research areas of faculties, but where can I find what grad students are working on and their contact info? Also when should I start cold emailing, and what should I put in the email? Should I just blatantly ask for an assistant position or I should first ask for an opportunity to talk?

tl;dr: A random person with no research experience wants to get into research. Are there other programs like URAP that I can apply through? Where can I find projects and contact info for grad students/profs for cold emailing? When should I start doing that and what should I ask for in the email? </md>
history.subject: How to get involved in research?
